page.title: 17Ecology 1
page.content: This area has remained a rich habitat for many animals. Farmers have not destroyed hedges in order to enlarge their fields, thus retaining a rich environment for wildlife. Common field birds abound and the rarer Curlew and Meadowlark live in the area. Gosshawks have been observed bringing down prey in flight. Water birds are abundant because of the many ponds and pools. These pools provide a resting place for migrants. There is a bird sanctuary, Jackson's Coppice, which is well used by local ornithologists. Foxes are common in this area and are seen both day and night, the local hunt meets twice each season. The woods are home to many badgers, which can often be seen in the lanes at dusk, searching for food. Continued.
